div.p: THE MYSTERIES OF THE CASTLE: A DRAMATIC TALE, IN THREE ACTS.
THE MYSTERIES OF THE CASTLE: A DRAMATIC TALE, IN THREE ACTS: AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN. WRITTEN BY MILES PETER ANDREWS, ESQ.
LONDON: PRINTED BY W. WOODFALL. FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW. 1795.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: FOR the PROLOGUE, and the SONG in praiſe of HAWKING, the AUTHOR is indebted to his friend Capt. TOPHAM. And he gladly takes this opportunity of acknowledging his obligation for the liberal attention of the MANAGER, and the ſpirited exertions of all the PERFORMERS.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: LONG has been ſerv'd from this our motley Stage,
Repaſts for various taſtes—from youth to age—
To lively Miſs, eſcap'd from Sſhool and toil,
Our ſports have oft beſtow'd the infant ſmile,
While the rude boy, from Weſtminſter or Eton,
Who "ſpies," and "quizzes" one, where'er they meet one.
For them, our brilliant Ballets drawn from Greece,
Reſtore their Greek—without a rod a piece.
While tricks and tumbling honeſt John employ,
Who drinks his punch aloft, and ſcreams with joy.
The wife is all for muſic, ſhakes and thrilling,
Old maids, from ſoft humanity, love killing:
Each has his taſte: for married life may ſay,
Not oft' two perſons think in the ſame way.
Our Bard, long known to you, this night makes up,
Of various beverage—a kind of cup;
Of Muſic, Pantomime, and graver ſcenes,
Perhaps a daſh of terror intervenes;
Should not all theſe ſufficient change ſupply,
If you condemn—there will be—Tragedy.
But, Britons, while a neighbouring nation's crimes,
Have ſpread war wide, and made theſe—"Iron Times."
Greet you, the moral virtues of the STAGE,
Which haply may amend an erring age:
That Arts and Sciences may take their place,
That the domeſtic ties may have their grace,
The rights of ſweet humanity be known,
And freedom fixed by law, reign like your own?

body.head: The Myſteries of the Caſtle: A DRAMATIC TALE.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: —A View of the City of MESSINA, the BAY, MOUNT AETNA, &c, &c.
SICILIAN GIRLS coming from the Hills, going to Market with Eggs, Garden Herbs, Fruits, &c. &c.

lg.l: We village maids to market go;
And with jeſt and jocund lay,
Nor ſtop to make our purpoſe known,
Till we've reached the deſtin'd town.
Then with ſmiles and court'ſy meet,

div.stage: As they go off calls after them.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: —Holloa! Damſels! Stop a little, and I'll eaſe you of your wares, I'll warrant you. Well, thank Heaven, we're arrived in a chearful country at laſt. looking about Bleſs me! What a charming air! And what a charming appetite it gives one! I have ſcarcely ſwallowed any thing but duſt for theſe three weeks, but here ends our tedious journey—Yonder is the city of Meſſina, and hard by reſides the man my maſter is in ſearch of—Why my maſter has left Savoy, to ſeek this interview with poor dead Julia's jealous huſband, I am yet to learn—Oh! Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: —At length, Valoury, the hurry of travelling is over—you now will have time to recover your fatigue.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Yes, Signor Carlos, and to loſe my appetite I hope; for the one is as irkſome a companion as the other.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Would my diſtreſtes could be as eaſily removed as yours—The ſhade of my departed Julia haunts me at every turn, and her injured memory calls aloud for vengeance.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, if grief or reſentment could reſtore her to life, I'd ſtarve myſelf into a paſſion with pleaſure; but as that is impoſſible, might I adviſe you, Signor, I ſhould recommend a temperate meal or two, before we proceed any further.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Temperate! Valoury, can anguiſh inſupportable be temperate! Liſten to the ſtory of my heart—That Julia, the hapleſs wife of the imperious Count Montoni, whom thou ſaw'ſt interr'd at Palermo—

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: And a melancholy ſight it was, Signor Carlos—I remember I was juſt ſitting down to an excellent barbacue, ſmoking hot, when the proceſſion paſſed the window; but ſo it is, whenever a man is upon the point of being happy, ſome curſed thing or other always interferes to chill his proſpects.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Think, Valoury, of an attachment begun almoſt in childhood, and improved with growing years; when love's ſoft wiſhes were ſanctioned by reaſon, and dear expectation nouriſhed by conſenting friends.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: What then was the cauſe of your loſing her?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Her father's avarice and ambition. This proud, indignant Lord, the Count Montoni, with large poſſeſſions, and extended power, was
captivated with my Julia's blooming charms, and, do I live to repeat it, tore her from me in the moment when ſhe was to have been mine for ever.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: But how came the Lady to conſent?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: There thou haſt touched the cord of anguiſh in my breaſt; that drove me from my native home, to ſeek in ſolitude a calm, which, alas, Valoury, thy maſter's heart can never more experience; that brings me back again on the wings of rage, and vengeance, to demand atonement for wrongs too great to be endured.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir! Has any thing happened lately?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Yes; from the amiable Conſtantia, the only ſurviving ſiſter of my hapleſs love, I learn by papers found ſince her deceaſe, that the moſt infernal arts were put in practice by the Count and his adherents, to bend the timid fair one to their cruel purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Mercy on me! My hair ſtands on end. They hinted too at Palermo, that the Lady's death was ſudden and extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: By baſeſt forgery ſhe was induced to believe I had already been wedded to another.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: To another indeed! As if Gentlemen of your prudent turn of mind, did not think one wife at a time quite ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: But the hour of retribution is at hand; meanwhile bear this letter to Conſtantia—Her father, old Fractioſo, is one of the Chief Magiſtrates in the city. I would on no account that he ſhould hear of my return; therefore be careful to deliver it into her own hands.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Truſt it to me, Signor, and Dad ſhall know no more of the buſineſs, than an Ex-Miniſter does of the Cabinet, or a faſhionable huſband of his wife's bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: From her you may learn tidings of my friend, Hilario, whoſe return from Germany I expect about this time; and I know, notwithſtanding her father's obſtinate prohibition, Conſtantia is not inſenſible to his deſerts.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: And a charming Gentleman he is; would he were here—his chearfulneſs would drive away your honour's melancholy—ſorrow with him, is like a bad Signet, it ſqueezes the ſurface; but leaves no impreſſion.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Hark! Here come the Falconers with their Hawks—we muſt not be ſeen, retire—be expeditious, and meet me at the Hotel.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: At the Hotel—ah! Sir, you need not doubt my expedition; for ſure no love ſick girl in Europe can be more ſharp ſet than is your honor's very hungry, humble ſervant.

div.stage: Enter MONTAUBAN in a Falconer's dreſs, with Hawks, &c.
A train of Sportſmen all in ſhewy apparel, with high plumes of feathers.

lg.l: Heighlo! Heighlo! The morning is up,
We've each of us had a ſtirrupping cup,
And of game we'll bring home a load—
Uncouple the Spaniels, and let the dogs try,
See the Partridge there on the wing;
Quick, quick! Jolly Falconer, let the hawks fly,
'Tis a pleaſure fit for a king.
Then mark the ſwift Hawk—ſee him now make his ſtoop,
Ah! Down goes the game! Call him in then! La leup! La leup!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Barons of old, and Princes ſo high,
The health of the field, and the Falconer's cry,
Drown'd even the pipes of their wives:
Our Hawks, they are a Gallantie ſhow,
With rings and feathers ſo fine;
The Falconer laughs at ſports below,
What Sportſmen to joys then inferior wou'd ſtoop,
When the ſummit of ſporting is Hawking! La leup! La leup!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Montauban, draw near; thy activity and diligence are commendable—are the Hawks ſtrong and eager?

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Well, my Lord—no doubt we ſhall have ſport.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Methinks I ſhall not ſport to-day—diſmiſs thy followers awhile—I would confer with thee in private.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: How ſhall your vaſſal repay this condeſcenſion?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt Annette, I think, Conſtantia's woman.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: I do, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And toy'ſt with her occaſionally?

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: The damſel has charms, and I admire them, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I do not mean to chide thee, gentle Montauban, nor thwart thy amorous purſuits— they may, perchance, enable thee to do me ſervice.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: O! Let me fly to execute your commands.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then, thus it is. I have reaſon to ſuſpect that Conſtantia holds ſecret correſpondence with Carlos, my avowed, and mortal foe; the man who in life's childiſh, thoughtleſs hour, ſtole my wife's affections; for whoſe ſake ſhe ſhun'd my embraces, and notwithſtanding her father forced her to be mine, with-held from me a huſband's lawful rights, and died the ſullen veſtal ſhe had lived.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me, my Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Exert thy influence with this forward waiting woman; careſs, cajole, do any thing thou canſt to diſcover, if poſſible, theſe dark proceedings; for know, thy maſter's peace, his fame, his honor, nay, his life, may be at ſtake.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Forbid it Heaven!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Haſt thou ſeen Bernardo, my truſty Steward lately?

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Not theſe two days as I think—he ſeemed wrapt up in thought, and deeply penſive.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Did he ſo? I do not wonder at it; for indeed, I dread his preſence. aſide He has done me ſignal ſervice, and I mean, as ſuits my character and ſtation, to give him due reward.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip's ever bountiful and good.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I thought to have met him here—he will not be tardy to attend—I tremble at the interview—yet how avoid it—it ſhall be ſo aſide, tho' Bernardo is deſerving of my warmeſt gratitude,
yet the load of obligation bears ſo hard upon my nature, I cannot, will not ſee him face to face, till opportunity afford him ample recompence.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Such ever is the caſe with noble minds!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do thou go forward—meet him on the way—give him this ring, as earneſt of my friendſhip—tell him we ſhall meet anon—meanwhile he'll reſt aſſured, my favour ſhall go hand in hand with his deſert to lateſt life—haſte thee, good Montauban.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Right glad I am this meeting is awhile delay'd; for tho' I have gone too far to recede, tho' injured pride, and wounded honor, demand from the offender due expiation; and though I am certain Bernardo has uſed every precaution to ſecure us from diſcovery, yet ſuch are the weak workings of my mind, there is a ſomething which I cannot ſhake off, that makes me ſhudder at the thought of ſeeing him.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Pardon me, Count Montoni, if I thus intrude upon your privacy, and dare to interrupt your progreſs.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha! My deteſted rival. aſide I ſee you dare invade the privilege of decorum, and intrude upon me like a lawleſs robber.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Spare your opprobrious epithet—it recoils upon yourſelf—who wa'ſt that robb'd me of my heart's beſt joy? The lov'd companion of my early years—the allotted partner of my future life? Who was't that baſely practiſed on a timid female, and in conjunction with a ſordid parent, led her
to pronounce unwilling vows, and meanly triumphed o'er a forced conſent?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I ſcorn your imputation, and deſpiſe your vanity; thus idle coxcombs, when their ſchemes are baffled, and the light froth that flatters giddy girls, are in more ripen'd years ſeen through and ſlighted, they know not how to bear their humbled pride, but fly to falſehood and abuſe for ſhelter.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Infamous evaſion!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go—learn to check this habit of conceit; learn to endure the freaks of female minds; and condeſcend to think, the gallant Carlos, tho' in the zenith of his youth's career, may ſometimes ſuffer from a jilting miſtreſs, while men, with leſs deſert, may prove more fortunate.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Your levity, Count Montoni, is contemptible, and your inſinuation ungenerous as unjuſt—did I not, ſoon as I heard the gentle maid had yielded to your ſolicitation, and, as I then thought, from worldly motives, abandoned the heart ſhe once had deigned to prize; did I not tear myſelf from my friends, my family, my home, quit the fond ſcenes where I had been ſo bleſt, and with a boſom bleeding at every pore, leave you to the uninterrupted enjoyment of your nuptial happineſs?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why then return to brave me unprovoked, and interrupt domeſtic grief? My wife is now no more; you can no longer plume yourſelf upon her favour, or attack the ſacred honor of a huſband.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience! Muſt I then repeat the wrongs thou haſt done me, and ſting thy hardened boſom with reproach?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go on—I'm proof againſt a ruffian's foul invective.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Draw then, and with thy ſword defend, what. with thy tongue thou can'ſt not.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis well I am prepar'd, elſe had thy murderous intent been gratified.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Baſe ſlanderer! But words are uſeleſs, I come not to remonſtrate, but to puniſh.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Have at thee then, aſſaſſin, as thou art!

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: What do I ſee? My Lord—my Lord—is this the method to ſecure your wiſhes?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bernardo! ſinks his ſword Then I muſt pauſe—no power on earth but thee could ſtay my arm.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I ſee you are now protected; but mark me, Count; my juſtice ſhall not ſleep till treachery like thine, feel the reſentment it deſerves.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Take my defiance with thee. Bernardo, thou art welcome! Indeed thou art. I did not think we ſhould have met ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Not ſo ſoon, my Lord! I came hither by your own appointment.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: True; I ſent a meſſage to thee, by Montauban, but no matter—this rencontre has determined me—we have no time to loſe—I had ſome compunction; but now rage and jealouſy reſume their ſway.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p:
Let them not tranſport you too far—
we have hitherto proceeded with diſcretion; but caution ſtill is neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The funeral at Palermo will lull ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: No doubt, my Lord, it will—but this intruder, Carlos, muſt be guarded againſt.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Vile miſcreant! His officious return has fixed my wavering reſolution, and nerv'd my trembling hand—to-night, at the caſtle let us meet.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: We will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Provide thee a torch—a ſpade—the dagger ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I ſhall not fail.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My truſty Bernardo, take this caſket, it contains jewels that belonged to—what ſhall I term her? They now are yours—I am reſolved—Oh love! what art thou to revenge!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in FRACTIOSO's Houſe—Large door in back Scene—Large window likewiſe, with dreſſing table, &c. &c. under it.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Hah! What—when—how—a tall, raw boned fellow, you ſay, will come into my houſe, whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes; and will ſee my young Lady, whether you will or no, and will ſhake you by the fiſt, whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: And he ſhall feel my fiſt too, if he dare incroach upon my premiſes.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: So I told him; but it ſignified nothing—Says I, my Maſter, though a ſweet-tempered, ſweet-ſpoken, good kind of a good-looking old gentleman—

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Pooh! What ſignifies all this foolery?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Not much, indeed, for he would not believe a ſyllable.—What then, ſays I, I ſuppoſe you think he is a little four-faced, croſs-grained, peeviſh, pettiſh, ſurly, avaricious—

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Hold your larum, do, Mrs. Minx, and come to the point at once.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Well. isn't this coming to the point at once.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: You ſay he has ſomething to communicate—What ſort of a perſon is he?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: He looks like a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Ay, an humble ſervant, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Humble indeed! I never ſaw a ſaucier fellow ſince I was born; he treats me with no more reſpect, than if I had been his equal.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: You are not his inferior in pertneſs, that I can warrant—Where is he all this time?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Below in the pantry, ſtuffing himſelf with a brace of the beſt partridges in the whole latder.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Ha! what—devouring my property—Run, Annette, fetch him before me this inſtant. Exit Annette. Partridges forſooth! Zounds! he's the moſt impudent marauder I ever knew—to plunder the garriſon, before a parley can take place.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what is the matter? Has any thing happened to diſconcert you?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Any thing! Yes! every thing—I am vexed—teized—threatened—eat up alive.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Mercy on me! who can have done all this?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Who? A man—and he would do as much for you, if he could get at you.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: A man, pray dont be alarm'd on my account, I'll face the danger.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: No doubt you would—You have face enough for any thing—I dare ſay he'd like a young chicken as well as a partridge—but I'll take care to damp his appetite—Oh! here he comes—Do you, Conſtantia, ſtand at that end of the room.

div.stage: Enter ANNETTE, and VALOURY gnawing a bone, and walking up to FRACTIOSO in an impudent manner.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: I never taſted a better bird in all my life.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Keep your diſtance, fellow.

div.stage: Walking from him, and putting Conſtantia away.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: What, you are the Lord of the Manor, I preſume—Do you want a Game-keeper?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: I'll ſoon let you know what you want—A Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Oh! oh! You're a Magiſtrate, are you?—Pray lend me your arm—I love to have Juſtice on my ſide.

div.stage: Takes him by the arm, and walks with him forcibly near Conſtantia.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Why, you audacious varlet, would you aſſault my perſon, after having ſtolen my property?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you quite miſtake me; I come to protect your perſon and property too— There are other people waiting to ſteal it—You know Signor Carlos?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Ha! Who—Carlos? Well—what of him?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Pleaſe to diſmiſs the Lady of the Bed Chamber.—I only ſpeak to principals in office—always mute before underlings.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Annette retire! And do you hear, let us have none of your liſtening tricks.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I liſten! I'm ſure there's nothing that underlings need ſtay for; for I fancy I leave both knave and fool behind me.

div.stage: Valoury ſhews the letter to Conſtantia as ſoon as ſhe is gone, ſo as not to be ſeen by Fractioſo.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Now, Sir, let us draw near to him, that we may not be over-heard.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Keep away child—Why ſhou'd we fear being over-heard—Come, ſirrah, what have you to tell us?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.stage: trying in vain to give the letter
sp.p: Signor Carlos, you muſt know, is—is—

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: What the devil is he? Have you got a pain in your ſhoulders, that you can't keep your arms ſtill?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: He is a great friend to one Hilario.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia
sp.p: Hilario! ſaid you What of him?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo
sp.p: That's no buſineſs of yours—Do you preſume to make enquiries after a fellow not worth a dollar—the greateſt coxcomb in all Meſſina.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: And the moſt impudent dog in all Italy—he once gave me ſuch a ſlap on the ſhoulder.

div.stage: Slaps Fractioſo rudely on the ſhoulder, and as he turns to reſent it, paſſes the letter to Conſtantia on the oppoſite ſide, as he turns.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Why, raſcal, ſcoundrel—how dare you treat me with ſuch familiarity?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: I aſk pardon! It's a way I have, I only meant to enforce my argument—but I have done—my errand is completed—mute as if your Honour was an underling.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Get out of my houſe, you impudent ragamuffin! This fellow's coming here, had certainly more meaning in it, than I have been able to diſcover. aſide. This is all your doing, Madam Headſtrong—One daughter had the perverſeneſs to die on purpoſe to plague me, and you ſeem determined to live on the ſame ſyſtem.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: O! Sir, think on my poor ſiſter's hard fate; let that be a leſſon to you. Had ſhe married the man of her choice, ſhe might now have been alive to thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: The man of her choice! What, that pauper, Carlos, the intimate friend of the prating puppy, Hilario, that you would throw yourſelf away upon. But I'll take care to prevent it— To-day you ſhall be lock'd up, and to-morrow ſent away to a nunnery.—Annette! Annette!
Where is the key of this apartment?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: In my pocket, Sir,

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Then take it out of your pocket, Ma'am, for I mean to put it into mine.

sp.speaker: Annette
sp.p: Lord, Sir! its faſtened to a great ſwinging bunch—I dont think I ſhall be able to got it off.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Then open the door with it on— for I am determined to keep my daughter under lock and key.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Not in that room, I hope, Sir; for they ſay, ſince poor Madam Julia's death, evil ſpirits have walked there.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Evil tongues have talked there, more likely—Give me the key directly.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I muſt change my ground, aſide. To be ſure, Sir, here it is. fumbling to get the key off If a young Lady will be obſtropolous, why, ſhe ought to be locked up.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: What, are you againſt me too?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: 'Tis every one's duty to be againſt you, when you run headlong to deſtruction. Shall I open the door, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Ay, do, child: I ſee you are a good, ſenſible girl, and more diſcreet than I thought you.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: The very words my grandmother uſed to make uſe of: poor old woman! Your honor always puts me in mind of her. trying the key. Fecks! I believe the key-hole is ſtopt up.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Stopt is it? Well, go and look for ſomething to clear it—You'll find a file, Annette, in the breakfaſt chamber.—No—now I think of it, I'll go myſelf, for the tea-cheſt was left open, I believe, and there's no truſting a waiting woman within the ſcent of ſouchong.—Take care of your young Lady till I return.

div.stage: Exit, looking back all the way.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I believe I can open the door now; Miſs Conſtantia, will you take a peep at your prison?

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Are you really what you ſeem, Annette?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I follow the way of the world, ma'am; but dont mind a little confinement, it's only a prelude to matrimony—look in, and ſee if there are any ſpirits, Opens the door, and HILARIO comes out in a travelling cap.—CONSTANTIA ſcreams.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Am I ſo frightful then, my deareſt Conſtantia! Does this travelling equipage make me look like an hobgoblin?

sp.speaker: Conſtantia
sp.p: In the name of wonder when did you arrive?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Not an hour ago—I paſſed thro' Italy on a gallop—croſſed the bay in a ſtorm, landed at the quay in a whirlwind, and flew like lightning to viſit my adorable, without waiting for my toilette, as you ſee; though many a trim barber eyed me wiſhfully as I ſcoured along the ſtreet, as who ſhould ſay, "would I might take your worſhip by the noſe!"

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: But how, Hilario, did you gain admittance?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: By the aſſiſtance of this, my better angel; ſhe that pretended to take your father's part.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am; I always take the blind ſide, and ſo I'll faſten the door on the inſide.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: But, Hilario, my friend, it will be impoſſible for you to continue here.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: But, Conſtantia, my love, it will be impoſſible for me to continue any where elſe.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Will you liſten to me?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
For ever, ſo you don't deſire me to leave you; after having ſcampered acroſs the Continent
like a greyhound, it were hard to be turned out like a mongrel; beſides it would be ſo ungrateful to your indulgent papa, who has thus kindly left us together.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Mark what poor Carlos writes, reads "I am returned to Meſſina, for the ſole purpoſe of avenging my Julia's death—ſhould you ſee Hilario, tell him I am deſperate, and may ſtand in need of his aſſiſtance."

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: A very pretty ſummons! Becauſe he's deſperate, he ſuppoſes I muſt be mad; and you, my Conſtantia, in return for the hole you have made in my heart, want to have a bullet popt thro' my noddle.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Unkind Hilario! You know the ſincerity of my character; though fully tinctured with my ſex's levity, I am above the little artifices which they generally adopt—notwithſtanding your eccentricities, I am convinced of the goodneſs of your nature, and believe me, it poſſeſſes all my eſteem.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: For that dear confeſſion, let me but touch the tip of the nail of your fore-finger, kiſſing her hand, and command me all over the world.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Fly then to your friend—conjure him to relinquiſh his deſigns—tell him my ſiſter's wrongs are buried with her in the grave; and ſay, his interference may renew our ſorrows; never can redreſs them.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
I fly at your deſire going to the door but hold—I believe I muſt fly through the key-hole, for Daddy Cautious has double lock'd the
priſon. noiſe-without Zounds! ſomebody is at the door.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Conſtantia! Annette!.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: As I live, it is the old one again! What ſhall we do? If you return into the other room, he'll ſearch it, and we muſt let him into this—for heaven's ſake, Sir, get up the chimney, or out of the window.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Then another old one, that you may have heard of, muſt aſſiſt me—do you think I can climb like a ſquirrel, or fall upon my legs like a cat?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Annette, open the door.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Do as he tells you, and rely upon me; if I can't tumble out of window, I can tumble in, which will be a much ſafer experiment; only prepare yourſelves with a good ſcream to honor my entree.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Annette, I tell you, open the door.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Coming, Sir—my Lady and I have been taking a little nap.

div.stage: Hilario opens the window, then puts his leg out, as if mounted on a ladder, affecting drunkenneſs, and ſpeaking to perſons in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Take away the ladder, my boys—I have done with you.
sp.stage: Annette opens the bolt of the door, and juſt as Fractioſo enters, Hilario tumbles from the window into the room, overſetting the dreſſing table, &c.
sp.p: Here I am old truſty!—I was determined to make you a viſit, and finding your doors lock'd againſt me, I made bold to come in at the window.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: That wicked dog, Hilario! Oh, you villain! I'll have you laid by the heels, that I will.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: That's right, father, take care of my heels—you ſee I have taken care of my head already.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: You're a houſe-breaker—you want to plunder my property, and run away with my child.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Damn your property—I'll have none of it; and as for your ſweet child, I adore her— and you too, old ſurly—I'll adore you too.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Help! Help! He will murder me, and ruin the women. Conſtantia, why don't you run for aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, there's no occaſion to be in ſuch a panic—it's only a drunken frolic— I dare ſay the gentleman will do us no harm.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: I dare ſay you'll think it no harm, let the gentleman do what he will.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Right, Sir—there your honour put me in mind of my poor old grandmother again.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: And this is the fellow you wou'd give me for a ſon-in-law?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Yes, I am he, Holofernes—I am the Very fellow—Come, give us your bleſſing, old boy, and who knows, but in good time, you may have a ſupply of young ones.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Give you my bleſſing? Give you a halter! Get out of my houſe, this inſtant, if you don't wiſh to be hanged up in the court-yard.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p:
Pray, Sir, be ſo kind as to walk down ſtairs—no doubt you have friends
in the neighbourhood, who may be uneaſy at your ſtay—Pray begone.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I am off—much adored nymph—damſel of divinity—I'll do what you deſire—ſteady, ſteady to my promiſe—farewell, old Coffer.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Away with you, you filthy ſot.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.stage: ſtopping his mouth with his hand
sp.p: Hold —hold—no words—I'll tell you a ſtory.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: I dare ſay you will—a thouſand. But leave my houſe, and never let me ſee your face again.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: You ſha'n't—you ſha'n't ſee my face, old Cormorant; for I'll come back in a maſk, and we'll have ſome fun, my man of merriment, we will. Harkee! Do you know me? imitating a maſquerade character I am ſon-in-law to little Fractie, the juſtice grinder, as croſs-gained a crab as any in all Meſſina. He poſſeſſes more ducats than I do doits, and yet thinks as much of burning an inch of candle, as I ſhou'd of illuminating the whole city. Nevertheleſs I'll hug the old rogue, that I will—I'll hug him into good humour.

div.stage: Goes to embrace Fractioſo, who roars out and drives him off.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Murder! I ſhall be ſuffocated— Help to turn him out returns and adjuſts himſelf Mercy on me! There is no ſecurity for one, either at home or abroad—All the bolts in the world can't keep a forward girl in the houſe, or hankering fellow out of it.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p:
Dear papa, you do not, indeed you do not purſue the right method to ſecure my duty, or your own peace. Would parents treat their children as friends, inſtead of keeping them at a ſevere diſtance, the ſocial communication of each
other's ſentiments, would enable one party to give better advice, and induce the other more readily to accept it.

sp.speaker: Anentte.
sp.l: Lock and key—no hold can be—

sp.speaker: Fractioſo,
sp.l: Still my ſhoulders feel the blow.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The outſide of an old Caſtle with large gates cloſed, a turret door is viſible in the interior of the Caſtle—a hole in the wall, that appears to lead to a ſubterraneous paſſage—The whole wears an appearance of great antiquity and ruins.
Enter CLODDY with a quantity of hares, patridges, &c.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Well done, Cloddy! Thee didſn't lay thy ſnares laſt night for nothing—By the dickens, here's as pretty a bunch of preſerved property as any juſtice would wiſh to ſee at his table; and a
pretty round ſum it will bring me, when I ha' got it ſafe houſed—for our old rich citizens do ſo like a tit-bit, eſpecially when it is prohibited—and why ſhould they not? They call me a poacher— mayhap, ſo I be—what then—ſo be other people. Its my belief as how its a pretty general trade.

lg.l: Every ſcheme by day or night
Friends to trap, the wit will try,
He tips the wink, and cocks his eye,
And while he looks ſo woundy ſly
Makes game, e'en of his brother.
See Miſs and Madam lay their ſnares,
While Miſs in dancing, reels and drolls,
With a hitch, and capering itch,

sp.p: Od ſo! Here's ſomebody coming! I muſt run into my old hiding place yonder—that hole under the Caſtle wall—it has uſed to be a rare ſnug place; but o' late I ha' heard ſo many ſtrange noiſes near about, I fear there be other people hiding as well as myſelf—rabbit it, here they come!

div.stage: Retreats into a hole under the wall.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: So, my poor friend, after the father had generouſly locked you into his daughter's apartment—he cooly turned you neck and heels out of his own ſtreet door.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Faith, ſomething very like it; or, notwithſtanding my attachment to your perſon, my love for another perſon's perſon, would have made me a truant to friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Impoſſible is it, that a man ſhould prefer being ſafe in a warm houſe, playing bo-peep with the bright eyes of his miſtreſs, to ſcampering acroſs a cold country for a game at piſtols with his friend's rival?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Notwithſtanding your pleaſantry, I am convinced you would go a great way to ſerve me.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Yes, and not a little way to ſerve myſelf—your kindneſſes to me, and our early
friendſhip will, I truſt, never be forgotten—you certainly ſtand ſecond—that is, after the ladies, in my account—but I myſelf, am at the top of the page, and you know its the faſhion now, to take care of number One.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: True my friend; and number One is at preſent tolerably ſecure—I have already had a rencontre with this dread adverſary.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Already! I hope you are not wounded?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Sorely.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Carlos! Where is it?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: In the heart, Hilario—deep—incurable—a ſurgeon's ſkilful hand may eaſe the poniard's ſtroke—time's healing finger is ineffectual here.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it. How much kinder the old greybeard is to me—as he totters round me with a grin, I whip his ſcythe from his hand, and cut off my ſorrows in the middle.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Enviable vivacity! Had not relendeſs fortune mark'd me for the child of woe, I might have ſhared in all your chearfulneſs.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: My dear friend, take comfort—let us return to the city—theſe deſolate old ruins don't ſeem to promiſe much entertainment— they've made me grave already.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: To me the world is all a void—Julia! my once deſtined Julia's loſt for ever! As they go out, a bell tolls in the Caſtle. Whence came that diſmal ſound?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: From that diſmal caſtle I ſuppoſe—let us begone—the toll of a bell always makes me nervous.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I thought this dreary ſpot had been uninhabited—who could have occaſioned it?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Who? Gaffer Belzebub, to be ſure— who the devil elſe would live in ſuch a place—I ſhall retire—he's not fit company for me.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Perhaps it is ſome perſon in diſtreſs— ſome lonely hermit, ſinking beneath the preſſure of diſeaſe!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Or, perhaps, ſome robber, who having tenderly murdered the lonely hermit, kindly reſolves to give him chriſtian burial.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Again—I am reſolved to ſee further into this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: And I am determined to remain totally in the dark—Carlos, I'm off.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Will you leave me Hilario? Can you deſert your friend?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What did you ſay? Deſert you— never—I may be at times, a little apprehenſive, but I never can forſake my friend—was the whole court of Lucifer armed againſt my Carlos, dam'me but I'd have a tuſtle with ſome of the cloven blacklegs.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Come then—ſuppoſe we try whether theſe antique gates will yield to our attack.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Move on—if the worſt comes to the worſt, it will be only bringing an old houſe about our ears—it won't do—old Ebony has faſtened them with his own claw.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.stage: going towards the place where Cloddy is
sp.p: Let us ſearch narrowly round the mouldering walls; time may, perhaps, have made ſome opening in them a light appears Softly—doſt: thou obſerve a light in yonder turret?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
A light! To be ſure I did—
the devils are at work—I think we had better leave them to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Mark! It moves along—now it diſappears.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I'm glad of it—we've ſeen enough— however, don't be afraid—I'll ſtick cloſe by you.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Here is actually a hole, ſeemingly under the wall; who knows but it may afford a paſſage into the caſtle—Heavens! ſomething living is concealed in it.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Be upon your guard, Carlos—don't venture in—it may be a wolf, or a tiger.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Then it muſt be a man tiger. However, be it what it may, I'll drag it forth—Shew thyſelf, fellow, and ſay, what brings thee here?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Brings me here! Why, iſe only fetching a walk.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Fetching a walk! What, in a hole in the wall? Zounds! this is the moſt impudent fetch I ever heard of.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: No trifling, ſirrah! Tell us who that caſtle belongs to?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Nan!

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Blockhead! does any one reſide in that caſtle?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Reſide! what be that?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Does any body live there? Anſwer this minute, or it ſhall be your laſt.

sp.speaker: Cloddy
sp.p: O lud! O lud! Noa. Nobody lives there but the rooks and ravens. To be ſure they ha'had ſome viſitors lately, and by their cawing and croaking, I dont think they much like their company.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What company are you talking of?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Why, ſpirits and hobgoblins, I believe; for I never heard ſuch ſhrieking and ſqueaking in all my born days.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Shrieking and ſqueaking! Hadn't we better get more aſſiſtance, Carlos?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What avails human aſſiſtance, if we are to encounter ſupernatural foes? Did you ever ſee, as well as hear, any thing extraordinary?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes, one night, when I was taking a walk.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What, walking again, friend? Well, what did you ſee?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Why, I feed a light in the South tower, and ſoon after, a ſort of a kind of an apparition appeared, and when I cried out, it called me fool.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Ay, claim'd relationſhip.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What was it like?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: There—look there it be again!

div.stage: A perſon with a dark lanthorn, muffled up, looks out from a turret-window, and then retires, ſhutting the window.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Something myſterious is certainly going on—I am determined to unravel it.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I hate myſteries confoundedly. However, I dont ſpeak becauſe I want to flinch—But it is ſo ill bred to pry into family ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Somebody is approaching—We have no time to loſe.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Its Maſter Montauban, with the ſportſmen—I muſt be off.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Off, fellow!—for what reaſon? who are you?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: I be Cloddy, own brother to ſiſter Annette, and ſhe be the ſame to me.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: How! brother to my Guardian-angel —Come to my arms, my ally from the hole in the wall—Annette aſſiſted me, and therefore you and I will fetch a walk together.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Wounds! An'you be ſiſter's friend, I'll do any thing you like; and if you want to peep into that old caſtle, I believe I can ſhew you a way under the wall; but you muſt ſtoop very low, and, mayhap, creep upon all-fours.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: No matter—point out the path—nothing can deter us. Horns again. Time preſſes— away—away.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I wiſh, with all my ſoul, we were fifty leagues away from this place.

div.stage: Exit thro' the hole in the wall.

lg.head: GLEE.
lg.l: What ſhall he have who ſported beſt?
A ſhout of joy from all the reſt—
The honeſt heart, no doubts will ſtart;
But join the ſtrain before we part;
The Horn, the Horn, the echoing Horn,
Shall rouſe the Sportſmen ev'ry morn;
On you the palm will fall, Sir;
No, not on one, but all, Sir;
Now ſends us all content away.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: An old room, hung with antique, tattered tapeſtry—two doors exactly alike in the back ſcene, covered with the ſame tapeſtry—A window over them, the ſtage to be a little darken'd.
Enter the COUNT, muffled in a cloak, and BERNARDO.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: At length, my friend, the hour of retribution comes; and love inſulted, claims its ſacrifice—the time, the place, occaſion—all conſpire, while ſecrecy ſecures revenge.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Would I could ſay ought to ſtay your purpoſe!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Impoſſible! 'tis now too late—Is not this favour'd rival come to vaunt his valour? Shall we reſtore the idol of his panting heart, and be ourſelves, the victims of his triumph?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Never my lord—her deſtiny is fix'd.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet, ſpite of the rage which fires an injur'd huſband's breaſt, reſiſted pity will at times intrude—fear too, appals, and dread remorſe— the very figures faſhion'd in theſe antient hangings, with ghaſtly eye-ball ſeem to frown upon us.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Weak imagery of the brain, which quick deciſion muſt efface—truſt me, my Lord, we have little leiſure to deliberate.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What mean'ſt thou, Bernardo?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p:
Not an hour ago, waiting, as is my duty, for your Lordſhip's preſence; a deep ton'd
bell, fixed unknown to me, in the interior of the Caſtle, was on a ſudden by our mourner ſounded.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: At firſt I thought 'twas fancy; but being repeated, I flew to trace the cauſe, and inſtant cut the rope.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twas well.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Soon after, the outward gates were by rude hands attempted to be forced.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Thou alarm'ſt me—

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: With ſpeed I mounted to the turret, and deſcried ſome ſtrangers in cloſe conference.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Didſt thou know them?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: The day declining, prevented more diſcovery—The ſportſmen returning from the field forced them to retire.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Who could they be? No matter—apprehenſion will but prompt our purpoſe—her doom's inevitable—but then—the remains.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: All is prepared—the coffin is at hand.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So ready, Bernardo—Yet, wherefore delay—danger may follow—bring hither the crow, the fatal dagger too—I left it in the portal, my hand refuſes—can I be the aſſaſſin? Stay awhile—yet no—begone—fly—give not horrid thought a moment's pauſe.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I will return, my Lord, as quick as the dark windings of this dreary manſion will permit me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
The night advances faſt— wherefore this inward pang, this ſtruggle of nature? Come, wounded pride, love ſlighted, ſcorned—come ſuffering honour, aid this weak heart,
and give it manly reſolution—huſh! was not that a ſigh, a deepened ſigh? How ſoon the laſt muſt follow, let me ſeize this ſolitary interval to take one final look, ſilent, unobſerved—alas! the dim light that glooms around, ſcarce ſhews the diſmal path.

div.stage: Enter CARLOS with a dark lanthorn and HILLARIO with a broken piece of a ſhield—they aſcend from a cavern.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Carlos! Carlos! Carlos! ſoftly—you go too faſt—thank heaven, at laſt we have emerged from that horrid cavern—zounds! I am as damp as a new newſpaper, and as muſty as old cheeſe out of a wine cellar.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: In truth, Hilario, it is ſomewhat ſurpriſing, after the extraordinary occurrences without the walls of this old caſtle, we ſhould as yet be able to make no diſcoveries within; a ſolemn ſilence ſeems to reign around, and nothing, ſave the hollow murmur of the wind, ſtrikes on the liſtening ear.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: A murmur of another kind, ſtruck upon my ear.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: You ſhall hear—but come a little further from that curſed cavern; you know, after having trampt about theſe diabolical apartments for half an hour together, we agreed to ſeparate at the end of a long gallery, and took different routs.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: We did ſo—and the diſtant glimmer of light from this lanthorn, which I found ſtanding on the pavement, led me to the diſmal receſs where we again met—but proceed—

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: The fact is, that old Ebony has been more attentive to me, than to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Will you be ſerious one moment?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Serious! upon my ſoul I don't think I ſhall ever be otherwiſe. I am terrified to death— I cou'd as ſoon raiſe the devil as a grin.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Torture me not with ſuſpenſe—but tell me all.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: That I will, if I can find breath to go thro' with it—firſt I deſcended ſeveral ſteps of a dark narrow paſſage—at the bottom I heard a door open, then the patting of a man's foot, whether cloven or not I can't ſay—ſoon after, I ſaw a light, ſo I made a pauſe, and ſaid to myſelf now dont be frightened, Hilario—now dont tremble, my dear fellow, but ſummon up all your courage, and boldly run away.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Would I had been there inſtead of you.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Would you had, with all my heart! tho' I defy you to run faſter—but in the attempt, I fell plump on my face, and in ſcrambling to get up, I clawed hold of this broken bit of a ſhield. There ſeems ſomething like letters ſcratch'd upon it.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Letters, Hilario! Try then, to decypher them.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: No, try yourſelf, I have got ſuch a mumbling in my mouth, and my teeth ſo chatter, that—

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Heavens! what's this I ſee? reads "Julia, wife to the Count of—was forced to this Caſtle—the marble hall—the dreary vault—Oh pity and remember" drops the ſhield 'tis the labour of my Julia's
hand, the unavailing record of her hapleſs fate— Oh my foreboding heart! ſhe has been murdered.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I'm all over in a cold perſpiration, we had better get into the open air—it may ſave us from a fit of the ague—I feel die quaking already.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Never will I quit this gloomy edifice, till I diſcover my poor Julia's ſad remains, dreadful idea!—the mangled relicks of her beauteous form.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Dreadful indeed! who knows but our forms may be mangled in the ſame manner.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Was it for this, I left my friends, my home? To abandon the dear object of my earlieſt vows, to coward fraud and ruffian violence, Gods! I ſhall run diſtracted!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Be adviſed, Carlos—let us retire.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: No faithful monitor to warn her unſuſpecting youth—no arm to ſhield her helpleſs innocence—heh! what noiſe was that?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What? the perſpiration is coming again.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: It ſounded like a groan.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Dear Sir, dont frighten one, more than there is occaſion.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Mark me—obſerve that window—do you not ſee a light?

div.stage: a light is ſeen to paſs

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: A Li—ght!

sp.speaker: Carlos.

div.stage: Runs out thro' one of the doors in the Scene.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Follow! I'm numb'd, I'm petrified—I have not a limb to ſtand upon—ſoft —let me try advances one leg yes, I have put my right foot foremoſt, no, let me take it back again. retreats a little Thunders again What ſhall I leave my friend in the lurch? let him grapple with old Ebony by himſelf? for ſhame, Hilario! after him, my boy! Goes towards the doors in the Scene, opens one on the right of that where Carlos entered, which diſcovers a Coffin ſtanding on a bier, with a lamp upon it. Wheugh! I'm dead and buried! a Coffin! ſhuts door and I dare ſay the ſexton will be here before I can ſay my pray'rs, mum! here he comes.

div.stage: Enter BERNARDO with a ſpade and dagger.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Count! Count!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: He miſtakes me for ſomebody elſe.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Your excellence!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Its an excellent miſtake, however.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: He—ere.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I have brought the ſpade and dagger as you ordered.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Give them to me.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: You feel cold.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Yes—its ſo hot.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Hot! its a dreadful night—but all will ſoon be over. I'll enter the receſs the back way, and lead the victim down the ſteps into the marble hall—'tis yours to give the blow.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Till then farewell!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.stage: the ſpade in one hand, the dagger in the other
sp.p: Give the blow! gad, if I dont take great care I ſhall get the blow. I ſhiver from head to heel like a top-ſail in a ſtorm. This murder-loving villian has kindly indulged me with two inſtruments, one to kill myſelf with, and the other to dig my own grave.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bernardo why do you loiter ſo? Is this a time for delay? what, ſilent; do you ſhrink at laſt? Give me the means—I'll do the reſt myſelf, faithleſs coward!

div.stage: Snatches the dagger and goes out.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Faithleſs coward! aye ſo it ſeems, elſe ſhou'd I leave poor Carlos to battle with theſe two butchers alone? No by heaven! Thunder aye, growl on, I'll extricate my friend or periſh with him opens door where Carlos went out bleſs me, how dark! would I had half a dozen lacqueys at my back with a flambeau in each hand. If a man muſt be executed, I think the more parade the better.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A large antique hall, with black marble pillars on each ſide, diſtant from the wings—an open arch at the back, diſcovering a ſtone ſtair-caſe, leading from an upper appartment.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
What could Bernardo mean? He ſeem'd fix'd and motionleſs. He will not ſure betray
me— impoſſible a noiſe of opening locks hark! the door opens—he leads her down—the dreadful ſcene approaches—I'll conceal myſelf awhile.

div.stage: Bernardo with a lighted torch in his hand, leads Julia down the ſtair-caſe into the marble hall.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: My duty is diſcharg'd—lady, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Bernardo! do not leave me thus— tho' in the lone receſs, where I have been ſo long confined, without one ſuccouring friend to cheer my ſolitude, tho' when you daily brought my ſcanty pittance, a gloomy ſilence mark'd your ſhort'ned ſtay; now, I conjure you, grant my laſt requeſt, ere ſuffering nature ſink to long oblivion— ſay, why am I now brought ſorth?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I but obey the mandate of my lord, your huſband.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My huſband! ſay my tyrant, murderer.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I muſt not liſten to ſuch epithets.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Did he not, under pretence of riding for my health, entice me to this ſequeſtered ſpot, attended only by yourſelf? Did he not, on a ſudden, force me from my horſe, drag me thro' various dark apartments, and lodge me in that vaulted room, from whence you now have led me?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Lady, he is here.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh ſtay—protect me—do not abandon a poor helpleſs female, to ſuch deteſted hands.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
'Tis well, Madam—I ſee your haughty ſpirit ſtill continues—ſoftneſs might have ſubdued my feeble
nature—and woman's tears, might have produced a womaniſh compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Fear not, ferocious man—no tears can ſoften thy obdurate heart, nor will compaſſion find a votary there.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Once again, I'll deign to aſk what puniſhment you think your conduct merits.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Talk'ſt thou of conduct! can'ſt thou mention wrongs? Thou who haſt injured me beyond deſcription—ſtabbed my fair fame; robbed me of health, and cut me off from every hope in life.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Thyſelf alone, hath wrought thy own undoing—hath cauſed the woes you have already borne—the pangs you yet muſt ſuffer—am I not thy huſband?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, profane not thus the ſacred appellation—a huſband! honor'd name! wooes the ſoft virgin in the morn of life—wooes, if her heart be free, and fairly wins, but thou—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well Madam! what of me?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: To gratify a baſe, unworthy paſſion— knowing my ſoul was wedded to another, left no diſhonourable means untried, to force a wretched maid, heart-broken, to your arms—had not diſguſted nature made me ſhun thee.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Call it not nature, but adulterous love— a wanton flame excited by another—an outcaſt, rejected by your parent.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Unhappy parent! who, miſled by treachery, and lured by gain, hath doom'd his child to miſery and death.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Art thou then prepared?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
If innocence and purity of mind be preparation, then am I ready. If, with a heart ſuſceptible
of every ſoft emotion, to have laviſhed all the tenderneſs of growing years, on one whom I am taught to think unworthy, whilſt a hated tyrant holds me at his diſpoſal, be the height of human woe, then is the grave my only refuge.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To make that grave more welcome— know, ill-fated fair, thy minion was not falſe!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Not falſe! not wedded to another.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No—devoted but to thee, he wanders o'er the earth, a wretched exile.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: You have pierced me to the ſoul—now draw thy murderous ſteel—thou can'ſt not wound me more.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To ſave you from a diſgraceful union, I plann'd this honeſt artifice—to ſave myſelf from ſhame, I brought you hither—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: To ſave thy own coward heart.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Coward! be advis'd—deſiſt—'twere fatal to go on.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, coward—to glut thyſelf in a weak woman's blood; alone—defenceleſs—loſt to every human being—none to protect—none to avenge her death—elſe had the valiant youth, whom thou, at diſtance, dareſt calumniate, awed thy daſtard ſpirit with a frown.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis too much— ſince thou wilt provoke.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Strike, monſter, ſtrike—for with my lateſt breath, I will adore his virtues, and execrate thy baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then breathe thy laſt.

div.stage: Enter CARLOS. Julia faints in his arms.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Hold—ruffian!—murderer!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Confuſion! he here! What ho! Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Revive, my Julia! Let me not again loſe you, thus unexpectedly reſtored.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh! ſave me from that tyrant!

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Be not alarm'd, my angel—recall your ſcatter'd ſpirits—'tis your Carlos, who implores.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Carlos! My long loſt, my unhappy friend!—Oh, my diſtracted thoughts! by what magic are you here?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: By that, which from the firſt moment I beheld you, influenced all my actions—by the magic of your blooming graces, the memory of our endearments, the miſery of our ſeparation, the dreadful uncertainty of your fate.—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Carlos! I have been ſadly uſed— Anguiſh and diſtreſs have been my portion, ſince you left me.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Did I leave you, Julia?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh no! Julia deſerted you—forſook the dear poſſeſſor of her firſt affections—But, tho' not yours, believe me, I have never been another's.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: How! Are you not wife to the Count? May I once more preſs you to this faithful boſom?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Deſiſt—it muſt not be— Time will unravel all—O Carlos! feel for your devoted Julia—And the more you hear of my misfortunes, the more you will reſpect them— Had I not believed you falſe, a parent's threat, a father's ſupplication, had been equally in vain.

div.stage: Enter HILARIO—BERNARDO's ſword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Dam'me, how I peppered him! the ſcoundrel—hah! my honored Lady Julia—he told me you was alive—let me thus ſpeak my joy.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Where have you been, my friend?— to whom doth that ſword belong?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: To one of the butchers, to be ſure— I have got him ſnug in a cloſet, and you may peep at him thro' the iron bars, as you would at a curioſity—I'll have him ſhewn for a ſight—Oh Carlos! had you ſeen my courage—I wanted nothing but a live lady to animate me—for the moment I heard how it was, Madam—I fought like a lion.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: You deſerve every thing.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I drove him down a ſtair-caſe—whiſk'd him thro' a trap-door—dragg'd him over the duſty rubbiſh—caged him—and here I am with his trophy—but what's become of the other butcher?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Fled, like a guilty coward—but I'll purſue him thro' the world.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: And ſo will I, into the next—Wheugh! my hand is in, and I could fight a legion of Belzebubs.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, my friends! let me conjure you to proceed no further—leave the wretch to the reproaches of a guilty conſcience, to the rage of diſappointed malice—Carlos you have ſaved my life, now protect my fame—conduct me to my father's houſe—there alone, my harraſs'd mind can be at peace.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Forgive the impetuoſity of a man, torn
with contending paſſions—agitated at once by love, reſentment, by hope, and by deſpair—your fame has ever been dearer to me than my own— let us then, quit this ſcene of horror, and reſtore my injur'd Julia to her paternal roof.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Attempt not, Carlos, to accompany me home—you know how much my father is incenſed againſt you—ſhould we be ſeen together, 'twill give ſuch colour to the Count's calumny, as may prove injurious to us both—for the whole ſtory will ſo crowd upon his mind—

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Egad, ſo it will—then the tables may be turn'd upon us, and Ebony make us appear as black as himſelf—now, leave every thing to me— Fractioſo and all—I am the man for the old one —if Lady Julia will truſt herſelf to my care, I'll undertake to convey her, unſeen, to the apartment of her ſiſter, my adored Conſtantia; and then we can manage her return to life with all proper decorum.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Lead on.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Muſt we then part ſo ſoon? Oh Julia, form'd for the enjoyment of ſocial tenderneſs, my heart is doom'd to ſuffer unceaſing diſappointment. At leaſt, let me conduct you ſafely thro' the arched vaults, and narrow paſſages, that fill this melancholy pile—then will I purſue the guilty Count, and conſign him to the vengeance of offended laws.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Take with thee, Carlos, all the love I dare to offer, every anxious with I freely can beſtow.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
And as you don't want any of my courage, I'll take it all with me, to guard my precious charge—and then, fire and tow! let me
ſee who will dare to come within arm's length of us.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What is to be done with the owner of your trophy there?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Ay, the raſcal in the pound—we muſt take him with us, and ſecure his evidence, by promiſe of pardon.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: But notwithſtanding your courage, Hilario, 'twill be as prudent to have ſome officers of juſtice to aſſiſt us.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Certainly—for the moſt dauntleſs ſpirit may be ſometimes ſeized with a cold perſpiration—but never mind—move on—I'll lead the way brandiſhing his ſword follow cloſe, if you pleaſe tho', and we ſhall ſooner be out of this curſed old den of Philiſtines.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Where can my young Lady be gone? I have ſearch'd for her all over the houſe—ſhe muſt certainly have gone abroad—and ſhe may thank me for the opportunity—how aſtoniſh'd ſhe will be, when ſhe knows what I have overheard —I muſt ſay, my talent for liſtening has been of great ſervice to me in life, and has help'd me to unravel a number of myſteries.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: A ſweet ſcented courtier once gave me a kiſs,
And promiſed me mountains, if I would be his,
But ſoon I found courtiers were callous to ſhame,
And mountains and mole-hills with them were the ſame.

sp.p: For that very night, when I was at my favourite amuſement, liſtening, I heard a ruſtling of ſilks upon the ſtair-caſe, there was my ſpark making love to my Lady's maid, rigged out in an old caſt off, of her miſtreſſes: ſo,—

lg.l: Soon I found courtiers were callous, &c.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: A widow, whoſe tears were unceaſingly ſhed,
For her ſpouſe, her protector, her all, that was dead;
Made me wonder the dame ſhould ſuch ſorrow ſurvive,
Till I found that ſhe had a kind couſin alive.

sp.p: For calling one day, with ſome bombazeen to renew her weeds with, I overheard a parley in the back drawing room, "come widow, don't carry on this farce any longer, its troubleſome to be ſqueezing out tears from morning to night, marry me at once, you know my merit—I managed your late huſband's buſineſs the laſt five years of his life."

lg.l: No longer I wonder'd the dame ſhould ſurvive,
When I found that ſhe had a kind couſin alive.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: A maiden of ſixty, ſo pure and ſo prim,
As tall as a maypole, and nearly as ſlim;
Proteſted her pleaſures in life were all o'er,
At length I perceived ſhe'd one comfort in ſtore.

sp.p: For being invited to a ſnug diſh of tea and a little ſcandal, I chanced to go ſomewhat ſooner than I was expected, and paſſing her chamber I heard the corner cupboard unlock, and the following ſoliloquy. "Come to my heart, my beſt ſupporter; man, faithleſs man, has ſlighted and deceived me, you are the only warm friend I have."

lg.l: So I plainly perceived, tho' laid flat on the floor,
Life ſtill has one comfort for maids of three ſcore.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Annette, what can have detained Hilario ſo long?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: What can have detained you ſo long? I have ſomething to tell you of the utmoſt importance.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: What mean you? For heav'n's ſake be explicit—has any thing happened to him?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am—to him, and to her, and to me, and to all the world.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: If you have any love for me, I conjure you to ſhorten the miſery of ſuſpence—ſay, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: No Madam—nor is ſhe dead—nor I— nor any body elſe—we are all come to life again.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: You rave Annette—or do you find delight in torturing your unhappy miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I torture you, my dear young Lady! I had rather torment a dozen lovers from morning till night, than give you one moment's uneaſineſs, but I am ſo confounded, and ſo overjoyed, and ſo perplexed, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: What can be the matter?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Why then, as I hope for one huſband at leaſt, I have ſome reaſon to think that my Lady Julia is not dead.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: How! My ſiſter alive?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: You ſhall hear—juſt now, as I was ſtanding in the paſſage, thinking of nothing, and peeping, as I now and then do, in a little pocket looking glaſs, who ſhould whiſk by me, but the Count Montoni.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: He look'd alarm'd and confuſed, and I am convinced he didn't know what he was about.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Becauſe he took no more notice of me, than if I had been the meereſt dowdy in all Meſſina—ſo I was determined to go and liſten at the door of your father's library, where they were lock'd up together.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: At firſt I heard ſome muttering about an old Caſtle, and then the words, "Carlos and murder."

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: "Carlos and murder!" Alas, my poor Hilario, no wonder you are not returned.

sp.speaker: Anette.
sp.p: Don't be uneaſy, Madam—I am certain no miſchief has happened; for I heard the old Gentleman exclaim, "Julia not dead, then Carlos muſt be laid hold of," and ſo, Ma'am I ran to acquaint you with the news.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: If you love me, Annette, ſteal ſoftly back again, and try if you can diſcover any thing further.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I will, my dear Lady—liſtening is my forte—and for ſounds, ſhew me who has a finer ear than myſelf.

sp.speaker: Conſtantia.
sp.p: My ſiſter ſtill living! Can it be poſſible? Some dreadful myſtery remains to be diſcovered—oh, Julia, how deplorable muſt have been your ſituation.

lg.l: In the cup of female life,
Every draught to maid or wife,
So the cup, of female life,
Bitter is, to maid or wife;

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: A Sea proſpect in the vicinity of MESSINA, with a view of SCYLLA and CHARIBDIS—SCYLLA is a rock, with a light-houſe upon it—CHARIBDIS, a whirlpool below, on which the light is to ſhine.
Suppoſed to be late in the evening, and the Stage to be ſomewhat darkened.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Sure as I'm born, a pretty tight ſportſman, ſomething queer is going to happen, by reaſon my right eye did ſo tickle and itch this morning—and our cat made up ſuch a woundy thick tail, that—but where o' the name o' dickens have I wandered to? Ho! I ſees—there be my old friends, Scylla and Charibdis—they ſay, whoever gets clear o' the firſt, falls plump down into the latter, that's for certain—if you don't break your head againſt the rock, you are drowned below in the whirlpool—ah, it's the fame with the women —the moment you get quitten o' one, pop you're laid hold of by another.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Oh brother! My dear brother Cloddy I'm glad I've met you—I'm almoſt frighten'd out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: That's unlucky—becauſe why—you ha' no great deal to ſpare.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Then I'm a true ſiſter—I take after you—but no matter—I have ſuch wonderful news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: It's no more than I expected—I thought our cat's tail did not ſwell for nothing—what be it?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Why, I never liſten—but I have a way of overhearing, you know.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes, I know you have—wounds, here's Scylla and Charibdis both in one—but on with you.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Well—I heard the Count tell my old maſter, that his daughter Julia, my dear loſt lady, was ſtill alive—that the great burial was all a flam —and that ſhe was found ſecreted in an old caſtle, under the protection of Signor Carlos, her firſt lover, who, he ſays, aided by Conſtantia, and Hilario, were the authors of the whole contrivance.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Odratten! I don't believe it—I believe that black dog I uſed to ſee on the parapet, was the real poacher; he and the Count, depend on't, were the knaves that laid the ſnares.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: So I think—and therefore I have ventured abroad this dark night, at my lady's deſire, in hopes I may be able to ſee Madam Julia, who, they ſay, is ſtill at the caſtle, and give her intelligence of the plots that are carrying on againſt her at this moment.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Oh! Ho! So then I find your great folks can carry on their plots in the dark, as well as us little ones.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes; the old Gentleman, at the inſtigation of the Count, has ſummoned the city guard to their aſſiſtance, and ordered the gallies to row round the light-houſe, in caſe Carlos and his friend ſhould put off to ſea; for he has reſolved this very night to arreſt, and convey them to priſon. Come with me, brother—there is not a moment to loſe.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: No—nor a moment to find neither; for here are the whole poſſe at our heels, and as I don't much like a priſon—why I'll make bold to ſtep behind that tree; and liſten, ſiſter, as you do, by way of overhearing.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: And ſo muſt I too, by way of ſecurity.

div.stage: Enter COUNT, FRACTIOSO, Guards, &c. &c. with torch lights.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Go forward with the lights, I tell you—I can't ſee an inch before my noſe advances This it is to be hauled out at midnight, when we ought to be ſnug in our beds.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Conſider Sir, the honour of your family, which muſt be ſupported.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: So I do, Count—I do conſider it—but I cant help ſaying I wiſh it could be ſupported in broad day, with a warm ſun over our heads—nothing can be ſo dreadful, as the ſhrieking of owls, and the croaking of frogs, when one muſt climb battlements, and dive into caverns.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Undoubtedly—and unleſs fame and property were at ſtake.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: There it is—was it not for one's property, I ſhould not much care.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Who knows to what lengths the conſpirators may go—detection may make them deſperate.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Zounds! ſo it may—that raſcal, Hilario, is one of the gang, I warrant.—He's a moſt deſperate dog, believe me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No doubt he is.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: That fellow, and his friend Carlos, have been my torment theſe five years, on and off. They come in at a window to one daughter, and lock another up in a Caſtle—look ye, Count, I can't ſay I ever doubted you and now I am convinced that Conſtantia — Carlos — Julia—that damn'd Hilario, and all of them, have joined in a conſpiracy to rob and murder us—for if they bring dead people to life, they can ſoon make live people dead.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You know, Signor, that your daughter Julia went to Palermo, at your own requeſt, for change of air; it was not then in my power to attend her—news was brought to us of her deceaſe, and funeral honours followed in due courſe this you are acquainted with—but you know not perhaps, that Carlos's ſervant, if not himſelf, was diſcovered prying about during the ſolemnity.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Zounds! I'm all over in a conflagration —where is the caſtle? which is the road? I'll ſeize them myſelf—hah! here are ſome of them—ſtand back—keep back with the lights—let's liſten— mum!

div.stage: Exit guards, and men with lights.
Enter JULIA and HILARIO, followed by BERNARDO, guarded.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Would we were at home! tis a dreary, diſmal journey, in the dead of night.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: No doubt you think ſo—ſince you have been obliged to ſeparate yourſelf from poor Carlos.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Did you mind that, Count—I told you I ſaw thro' the plot— there's no deceiving me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I dread the meeting with my father— he is ſo credulous and partial to the Count.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I know it—but if he won't believe his own eyes, and will perſiſt in perſecuting you, do you think I'll ſtand tamely by—no—as I have brought you from one old tottering fabric, I wont ſee you entomb'd in another.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: You wont,—you imp—you puppy, wont you?—Count—guards— ſeize him—he is the wicked one.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: No—ſeize the Count—there he ſtands; he is the wicked one. Guards ſeize Hilario. What are you about?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Keep off, cockatrice—I ſee thro' it all—you can't impoſe upon me, didn't you pretend you was dead—put the whole family to the expence of new mourning, and make us cry our eyes out.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh my honour'd parent! liſten to your child.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Regard her not—falſe to her huſband, will ſhe be juſt to her parent?

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p:
I wont hear a word—you're an ungrateful
girl, and as low minded as that raſcal we have caught you with—you would rather live in an old cellar with Carlos, than in a ſuperb manſion with the noble Count, your huſband.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Unhand me, that I may tear that noble monſter piece-meal—come forward you penitent tool of authority—you promiſed, if I wou'd unpound you, to ſpeak the truth?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Speak Bernardo! you can protect me from the ſlanderer's tongue, but for you I had fallen by the poignard of that aſſaſſin, Carlos, who having ſtained my honour, wou'd have dyed it deeper with my blood.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: True my lord—but for me, your life had been ſacrificed. But for me, your fame would now be deſtroyed—give me liberty, and I will fully explain the guilt of Carlos, and his vile aſſociates.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Guilt of Carlos! oh Belzebub! that thou ſhould'ſt ſuffer mortals thus to outdo thee.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Stop that fellow's mouth, and releaſe Bernardo—I want no further proof—Carlos ſhall be hang'd, and you ſent to the gallies for life.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What, tie me to an oar!—Is this the way a grandee ſhou'd treat his future ſon-in-law.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Will nobody ſtop that fellow's mouth? You, Madam, ſhall be convey'd to ſome remote diſtance, to try if confinement will reſtore you to a ſenſe of your duty.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Confinement, alas, has itſelf no terror for your child—But if nature yet pleads for me in your breaſt, Oh, let my priſon be my father's home—devote me not again, to horror and to death.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: What do you mean by being devoted? Isn't the Count, your huſband, a man of honour—a man of fortune, rank and title?—you would be devoted only to that villian Carlos.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Carlos is not a villain—I'll tell you what—his ſoul is right honourable, every inch of it, whilſt that of the Count is like the old ſhabby bit of parchment that deſcribes his titles—black, white, narrow, cold, and ſhrivelled.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Contemptible defamer!

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Here's a fellow! talk to me of a ſhabby bit of parchment—I that am Vice Legate, Proetor, Nuncio, Viguier, Rota, Scrota, and ſo forth—away with him to the gallies—away.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: On my knees let your unhappy daughter ſue to you for juſtice—tho' doomed herſelf to inevitable deſtruction, let not her brave deliverer be the victim of his own compaſſionate heart.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Spare yourſelf the trouble, Ma'am— I have done my duty as becomes the future ſon-in-law to a grandee—life's an eternal ſee-ſaw—now I am a poor galley ſlave—in a month, perhaps, I may make a cockſwain—in another, captain of a ſquadron, and in a third, Vice Legate, Proetor, Viguier, Nuncio, Rota, Scrota, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Fractioſo.
sp.p: Take him away, I tell you, and clap him in irons.

Now Count, we'll go and engage a veſſel—meanwhile Mountaubon, with ſome choſen ſoldiers, ſhall purſue Carlos—We'll revenge ourſelves I warrant—an impudent ragamuffin, to compare me to a ſhabby bit of parchment—zounds! I'll have his hide ſo tann'd, that a troop of drummers
may find employment upon it—lead on, torchbearers!

div.stage: ANNETTE and CLODDY, come from behind trees.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Here's a pretty buſineſs! talk of my laying ſnares! why, no poacher in all Sicily can trap this fox of a Count—odratten it! I ſhould like to unkennel him.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Do, my dear Cloddy—think how they've treated that ſweet, kind hearted, laughter-loving Gentleman, my young miſtreſſes favourite.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes; and I knows he to be innocent— for I myſelf ſhewed him into the caſtle—and if ſo be, I had na been afraid of ghoſteſſes, I would ha' gone in too.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Dear, dear, how my poor young lady will take on—ſhe was ſo eager to ſee her ſiſter again, and ſo anxious to find her lover again, that ſhe prevailed on Valoury, Carlos' ſervant, late as it was, to endeavour to hire a boat—and I ſhou'dn't be at all ſurprized if ſhe was to croſs the bay to the caſtle this very night—hiſt! isn't that muſic on the water.

div.stage: Some notes of muſic are heard at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes—ſure enough it is— hark! it comes nearer—its ſome boatmen ſinging as they row to ſhore—let us hide ourſelves again.

div.stage: A row-gally with lighted lantherns on board is ſeen at a diſtance, rowing towards the ſhore—muſic and voices are diſtinguiſh'd, Chorus at firſt faintly heard, gradually growing louder—a noiſe like the ſplaſhing of oars occaſionally diſtinguiſhed.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Boatmen.
sp.l: As we plow the placid main,
Now of Scylla's rock take care—
Hold—now take the ſtaff in hand;
Spring on ſhore—we've reach'd the land.

div.stage: CONSTANTIA, veiled is handed out of the galley by VALOURY.

sp.speaker: VALOURY.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo dark, I wond'rous glad am,

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA
sp.l: Thank ye, friends, for all your trouble,
Stay, and I'll reward ye doubles

sp.speaker: Chorus of Boatmen.
sp.l: Glad we wait for your commands.

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA.
sp.l: Tell us where the Caſtle ſtands.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Boatmen.
sp.l: There it hath for ages ſtood.

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.stage: —coming forward, as they are going off.
sp.l: Stop, deareſt lady—the birds are all flown—
Your father—your ſiſter, your lover are gone.

sp.speaker: CLODDY
sp.l: The old one, for certain, has carried them off.

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA.
sp.l: Annette, is it you—do you treat us with ſcoff?

sp.speaker: VALOURY, CLODDY, and CHORUS.
sp.l: What old one, what old one, has carried them off?

sp.speaker: Duett—ANNETTE and CLODDY.
sp.l: If you ſtay, you'll be undone.

div.stage: Voices without, echoed by voices in ſeveral gallies coming to them.

sp.speaker: CLODDY.
sp.l: As we told you, we're undone.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Sailors—landing.
sp.l: Stop, and ſeize them every one.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Soldiers—ruſhing from the wings.

div.stage: Chorus of Soldiers returning with CLODDY, VALOURY, Ladies, &c. Sailors aſſiſting

sp.speaker: MONTAUBAN.
sp.l: Straight to priſon you muſt go.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Soldiers, &c.
sp.l: When you ſuffer, you will know—

sp.speaker: VALOURY and CLODDY.
sp.l: Oh, ho, ho, ho! Oh, ho, ho!
That will be too late to know.

div.stage: Duet—CONSTANTIA on one ſide of MONTAUBAN, ANNETTE on the other, lifting their veils.

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA.
sp.l: Is it thus a young Lady you uſe?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE.
sp.l: Or thus a kind ſweetheart abuſe?

sp.speaker: MONTAUBAN.
